To encrypt the plaintext "MATH" using the Hill cipher, we first convert the letters to their corresponding numbers (A=0, B=1, etc.):

M = 12
A = 0
T = 19
H = 7

Now, we arrange these numbers into a 2x2 matrix:

\begin{bmatrix} 12 & 0 \\ 19 & 7 \end{bmatrix}

Next, we multiply the given key matrix by the plaintext matrix:

\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 1 \\ 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix} * \begin{bmatrix} 12 & 0 \\ 19 & 7 \end{bmatrix}

To perform matrix multiplication, we calculate the dot product of each row in the first matrix with each column in the second matrix:

(4 * 12) + (1 * 19) = 48 + 19 = 67
(4 * 0) + (1 * 7) = 0 + 7 = 7
(3 * 12) + (5 * 19) = 36 + 95 = 131
(3 * 0) + (5 * 7) = 0 + 35 = 35

So, the resulting matrix is:

\begin{bmatrix} 67 & 7 \\ 131 & 35 \end{bmatrix}

Now, we need to take the result modulo 26 (since there are 26 letters in the alphabet):

\begin{bmatrix} 67\mod{26} & 7\mod{26} \\ 131\mod{26} & 35\mod{26} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 15 & 7 \\ 3 & 9 \end{bmatrix}

Finally, we convert these numbers back to letters:

15 = P
7 = H
3 = D
9 = J

So, the encrypted text is "PHDJ".
